properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A slow moving low pressure system over Northwestern Ontario will move over Hudson Bay Wednesday. Rain and gusty northeast winds will move into the Arviat area tonight and then spread northward up the coast Wednesday. These rainy and windy conditions will end Thursday when this weather system moves into northern Hudson Bay. Rainfall totals of 30 to 40 mm are likely for this weather event. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-08-28T23:18:54-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-08-28T07:19:54-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3478817765.2019
Area: Arviat
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Tropical system Erin or its remnants will approach western Nova Scotia Thursday evening and then track across Prince Edward Island Friday morning. Rain at times heavy and gusty winds are expected as it moves through. Total rainfall amounts of up to 60 millimetres are possible. Southeasterly wind gusts to 60 or 70 km/h are also possible. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2019-08-29T02:54:52-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-08-28T18:55:52-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3820394962.2019
Area: Kings County P.E.I., Queens County P.E.I., Prince County P.E.I.
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Tropical system Erin or its remnants will approach western Nova Scotia Thursday evening and then track into the Gulf of St. Lawrence Friday morning. Rain at times heavy and gusty winds are expected across most of Nova Scotia as it moves through. Total rainfall amounts of up to 60 millimetres are possible but lesser amounts are expected across eastern areas of the province. Southeasterly wind gusts to 60 or 70 km/h are also possible. At this time, warning level storm surge and coastal impacts from high waves are not expected. After midnight into Friday morning, waves near 4 metres will spread from west to east along the Atlantic Coast of Nova Scotia and will break higher along the beaches. Rip currents will also be an issue, and the public should exercise caution near the coast. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-08-29T02:33:11-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-08-28T18:34:11-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0883183215.2019
Area: Kings County, Annapolis County, Digby County, Lunenburg County, Queens County, Shelburne County, Yarmouth County, Cumberland County - Minas Shore, Cumberland County North and Cobequid Pass, Colchester County - Cobequid Bay, Colchester County North, Hants County, Colchester County - Truro and south, Halifax Metro and Halifax County West, Halifax County - east of Porters Lake, Pictou County, Guysborough County, Antigonish County, Richmond County, Inverness County - south of Mabou, Inverness County - Mabou and north, Victoria County, Sydney Metro and Cape Breton County

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A large low pressure system over Hudson Bay will bring significant rainfall to the south coast of Baffin Island on Thursday. In Kimmirut rain will begin overnight, accompanied by strong southeast winds gusting to 50 km/h. Rain, heavy at times, will continue through Thursday and Thursday night before ending early Friday morning. Total accumulations between 35-55 mm are expected by Friday morning. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-08-29T11:42:36-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-08-28T19:43:36-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3836384465.2019
Area: Kimmirut
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Summary:
Description: Tropical system Erin or its remnants will approach western Nova Scotia Thursday evening and then track into the Gulf of St. Lawrence Friday morning. Rain at times heavy will begin Thursday morning over southern sections of the province and then taper off by Friday morning. Total rainfall amounts of up to 60 millimetres are possible. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A slow moving low pressure system, which is bringing significant rain to the Churchill area, will continue to bring rain and strong gusty northerly winds to the region today and Thursday. Rainfall totals thus far up to 10:00 am have reached 47 mm and a further 15 to 25 mm is expected before tapering off late Thursday. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2019-08-29T07:27:14-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-08-28T15:28:14-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1019311183.2019
Area: Churchill
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing large hail. Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms capable of producing hail up to 2 cm today. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2019-08-29T02:26:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-08-28T18:28:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3132037913.2019

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 12:34 p.m. CST, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a severe thunderstorm capable of producing strong wind gusts, up to nickel size hail and heavy rain. The thunderstorm is located over Beaupre Lake and is moving to the southeast. Nickel-sized hail has been reported with this thunderstorm at Dore Lake. Green Lake itself should not be expected. ### Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.
Expires: 2019-08-28T21:33:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-08-28T18:35:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1639239485.2019
Area: Green Lake
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Tropical Cyclone Information Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: For Tropical Depression Erin. The next information statement will be issued by 09:00 p.m. ADT. Tropical Depression Erin will begin tracking northeastward toward the Maritimes later today. Erin is expected to transition to a post-tropical storm well before it reaches southwestern Nova Scotia early Friday morning. Erin will bring heavy rain to much of the region beginning Thursday and strong, gusty winds with its passage Thursday night into Friday. 1. Summary of basic information at 03:00 p.m. ADT. Location: Near 33.7 North 73.1 West. About distance 284 kilometres southeast of Cape Hatteras NC. Maximum sustained winds: 56 kilometres per hour. Present movement: North at 20 kilometres per hour. Minimum central pressure: 1005 millibars. 2. Public weather impacts and warnings summary. Tropical Depression Erin is expected to transition to a post-tropical system by the time it enters Canadian waters on Thursday. Rain associated with a trough of low pressure approaching from the west will spread over the western Maritimes early Thursday morning. As Erin approaches later on Thursday, some of its moisture will feed into this trough and likely enhance the rain intensity associated with it. The heavier rain and strongest winds associated directly with post-tropical Erin should reach the Atlantic coast of Nova Scotia later Thursday evening. a. Wind. Some gusty winds will likely accompany post-tropical Erin, especially to those areas just to the right of its track early Friday morning. At this time it is not expected that these winds will reach warning criteria (i.e. gusts to 90 km/h or higher), but could still be strong enough to cause isolated power outages and minor damage, especially given that trees are still in full leaf. b. Rainfall. The combination of Post-Tropical Erin and its interaction with the trough of low pressure crossing the region on Thursday will combine to produce significant rainfall. Rainfall will likely meet or exceed warning criteria (50 mm or more in 24 hours) in parts of the Maritimes, especially those areas just north and west of Erin's track. Some isolated locations in these areas could possibly see total rainfall amounts in excess of 100 mm before the rain ends later Friday morning c. Surge/Waves. At this time, warning level storm surge and coastal impacts from high waves are not expected. However, some higher than normal water levels and high surf are possible near and to the right of the Erin's track where it is expected to cross the Atlantic Coast of Nova Scotia on Friday. After midnight into Friday morning waves near 4 metres will spread from west to east along the Atlantic Coast of Nova Scotia, and will break higher along the beaches. Rip currents will also be an issue, and the public should exercise caution near the coast. 3. Marine weather impacts and warnings summary. Gale warnings have been issued for the southwestern Maritimes marine waters, where gale force southerlies up to 40 knots are expected by Thursday evening. These gale warnings will likely be extended to adjacent marine areas for Friday near and along Erin's path through Canadian waters. Forecaster(s): Mercer/Borgel ### Please continue to monitor alerts issued by the Canadian Hurricane Centre and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-08-29T23:39:39-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-08-28T17:40:39-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2074932776.2019

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. Dense fog has formed over Resolute Bay and is expected to persist until this afternoon. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:

Strong northerly winds gusting as high as 80 km/h are expected to continue tonight through Thursday as well. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts, large hail and heavy rain. A low pressure system tracking rapidly through the northern Grain Belt of Saskatchewan is triggering scattered thunderstorms this afternoon. Some of these thunderstorms could reach severe thresholds. The threat for severe thunderstorms will diminish this evening as the system tracks out of the province into Manitoba. This severe thunderstorm watch may be expanded eastwards later this afternoon or early this evening as the system tracks southeastwards. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2019-08-29T05:06:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-08-28T19:04:20-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0873657387.2019
